Here you may finde civility.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Pray heaven I may, my journey hither hath.
Been full of ſtrange misfortunes—I have found
Crown'd expectations for captivity
Unhappily exchang'd.

sp.speaker: Sai.
sp.l: Valiant Bandeets farewell—look to your charge.

sp.speaker: 3. Ban.
sp.l: With as much care as we would ſtrive to keep
Jewels, whoſe loſſe would ruine all our hopes. Ex. Sai.,

sp.speaker: 3. Ban.
sp.l: Come noble Lady—if your birth hath cloth'd
Honour in higher attributes, forgive
Our rudeneſſe, ſince the child of ignorance.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Alas! what ere my birth hath been, I'm now,
A ſlave to you, and muſt forget thoſe vain
Airs of ambitious honour, ſo I may
But find civility enough to be
Protectreſs of my Virgin honor, all
My others will moſt willingly be ſpar'd,
Yet they are ſuch that were I known I might
Perhaps repair theſe broken fortunes which
Thus makes you run the hazard of the Law.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: We wiſh this curtain of your fate may be
Swiftly withdrawn, till then, let all our vowes
Prevent your fears, the rudeneſſe of our lives
May be your trouble, but ſhall never grow
To a diſeaſe more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I live in hopes to gain ability
Of an extent ſo large as recompence. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter three Blades, Buff. and Gndgeon drunk, Drawers with Wine.

sp.speaker: 1. Bla.
sp.p: Stand up brother—come, our brains are not warm enough yet—fill out—here noble brother.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Thanks brother Collonel—I will pledge thee were it a Tub full—and pay for't too—here's gold enough.

sp.speaker: 2. Bla.
sp.l: Here—a health to my Lord Arratus.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Come to my Nunckel—there lies my hat.

sp.speaker: 3. Bla.
sp.l: Here Gudgeon, thou muſt have it too.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: I ha more already then I can carry upright.

sp.speaker: 1. Bla.
sp.l: Round with another health—here
To my brother Buffonies Lady.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: That's the two yong Gentlewomen of the houſe—
Theſe be Gallants Gudgeon—ſons of fame.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: She blew them from her breech.

sp.speaker: 2. Blad.
sp.p: Houſe—more Wine. here, where be theſe Vermin?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: What will they not hear?—let's break down the doors Brother,
Or fire the houſe—nay I am valiant too.

div.stage: Knocks, a Wench looks out a the window.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Why, what d'ee mean there Gentlemen to beat my mothers doors down?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Some Wine and Wenches you Cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.l: You have too much already Sir, to ſleep—

sp.speaker: 1. Bla.
sp.p: Why you harpy, doeſt think we'l be confin'd to the Lobby.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.l: You will have the greater benefit of the air Sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Bla.
sp.l: Swounds we'l not be bafl'd thus.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: No that we will not brother, I feel the ſpirit of Wine in my brains, and will not be bafl'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Bla.
sp.l: We'l ſcale your windows you Whores.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Brother—let's—brother Collonel—Ile in firſt.

sp.speaker: 2. Bla.
sp.p: We will not put you on a matter of ſuch danger Sir.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Danger—I ſcorn the word—I fear it not brother, Ile do it—I and my valiant ſword-bearer.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Ile not creep in at windows, not I, amongſt Whores to have my eyes ſcratch't out—not I.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: How—not venter? why thou wilt not turn coward and fear ſcratching?—ſhall not be ſaid but we Countrey boys are as valiant as the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: 3. Bla.
sp.p: But the window is narrow, and will ſpoil your new ſuit.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Come, come—prepare—help me and Ile put them off.

sp.speaker: 2. Bla.
sp.p: Valiant brother, thou ſhall have the honour to enter firſt.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: I and my ſquire will enter this inchanted Caſtle,
And relieve the impriſon'd Ladies.
Gudgeon let's untruſſe and prepare for the combate.

sp.speaker: 1. Bla.
sp.l: Ile help my brother whilſt you prepare Gudgeon.
—Now for the boots.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: My foot is at thy ſervice noble brother,
Nay off with my breeches too—I have drawers on.

sp.speaker: 2. Bla.
sp.l: Haſt thou drawers too Gudgeon?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: I, but I had as leave a been hang'd as ha come to this.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Come now, your helping hands, Ile ſcale the wals,
Attendant be at hand with my weapon.

sp.speaker: 1. Bla.
sp.l: We'l ſecond thee immediately venturous brother.
Come Gudgeon follow thy Maſter.

div.stage: Put them in at the window.
Outeries within.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Oh—oh—help us brother Collonel,
Draw up thy forces.

sp.speaker: 1. Bla.
sp.p: The conflict is begun—we'l leave them to the mercy of the Wenches, and now the guls are uncas't make uſe of their feathers—here's a prize lads.

sp.speaker: 2. Blad.
sp.p: The Golden fleece was but ſtinking ſheepskin to't.

sp.speaker: 3. Blad.
sp.p: Come let's be gone, the Bloud-hounds will purſue.

div.stage: Enter Creon and Lewcippus.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Pox on the ſlaves they're gone.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: This Devill Luſt hath undone us.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Tis no now time to diſpute it;
Let's rather bethink our ſelves of ſome courſe
To preſerve our credit with his unkle.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: There's it, and I am deceived, if I have not found it out; thou knoweſt the opinion he hath of his valour: I will home, and poſſeſſe him that he privately withdrew as we fear to fight, and that thou were in queſt of him whilſt I come to inform his doting Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Bleſſed be thy pregnant brain,
Be gone and thrive, I will return upon my cue. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Buffonie and Gudgeon in their ſhirts—both bloudy, wenches following.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.l: Out of my doors you Rogues.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Good reverend Matron—we heartily repent—Gudgeon our clothes—what's become of our brother Collonel, and the reſt of the Blades?

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.p: Faith even ſheathed in your ſcabards by this time, you ignorant Rogues to come to abuſe a civill houſe and be couzen'd of your clothes.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: Oh we ſhall die with cold.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Good Gentlewomen give us ſome ſlender garments, my Nunckel ſhall give ſatisfaction—Oh Gudgeon my Hat and all my fine Ribbons, and my Sword—all's gone.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: I woot we had our old ones here.

sp.speaker: 1 Wen.
sp.l: But faith tis pity to turn them off thus,
The puppies will catch the pip—have you no old breeches?

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: By my fay nothing that belongs to man, but an old armour that a beggerly Souldier pawn'd—and that Ile fetch.

sp.speaker: 2. Wen.
sp.p: And Ile lend the page an old petticoat and waſtcoat.
sp.stage: Bring forth an Armour and clothes.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: We ſhall be bound to pray for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.p: Go arme the Knight whiſt I prepare the Lady of the lake.
sp.stage: Put the Armor on Buffonie, the petticoat and waſtcoat on Gud.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: I doubt we ſhall not paſſe the ſtreet for the Scoundrell boyes.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Put it on Gudgeon, and be thankfull.
Any thing to hide thy nakedneſſe, good Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: I have played maid Marrian ere now.

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.l: So now you are provided, my honour'd Don.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: We kindly thank your good Ladyſhips, we ſhall be bound to pray for you—tis not ſo cold as 'twas.

sp.speaker: 2. Wen.
sp.l: Come, march my valiant Hector.

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.p: Nay faith here is each of them an old pair of ſlippers too.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Good-be-wy my honourable young Ladies.

div.stage: Ex. Buf. and Gud.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.l: So now let's in and ſhare. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Arratus, Carlo, Theocrine, and Lewcippus.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: I wonder at this—when ſaw you him laſt?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p:
Some three hours ſince, when leaving him at a Play, whilſt we went to diſpatch ſome buſineſſe in the City, at our
return we miſt him—I perceiv'd ſome difference betwixt him and a blade oth' town, and doubt the ſword hath diſputed it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tis moſt like that's it, he is reſolute.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Muſt I then be ſo unhappy when I firſt began to cheriſh love to loſe its wiſht for object?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Grieve not Lady—I hope all is well.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I doubt his valour will betray him to
Some deſperate quarrell, in whoſe fury all
My hopes of him may periſh.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I will go ſend my ſervants abroad,
We cannot be too carefull of his ſafety.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Trouble not your ſelf Sir—I have took order.

div.stage: Enter Buff. and Gud.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: —Ah—ah—ready to die with cold.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: What have we here? a prologue to the mask of Witches?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Some intended ſport without queſtion,
Which now will come out of ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Ha! forgot me Nunckel—I am your poor kinſman.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Thou art my ſhame, and mak'ſt me grieve that ever
I entertain'd a thought of raiſing thee
So much beyond the pitch of thy deſerts.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let not your anger Sir
Add waights to his unhappineſſe.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Sure ſhe is bewitcht—you are a moving advocate,
But ſo it render him not loſt within
The place he did in your affections hold,
I ſhall be eaſily wrought to pardon him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That were a love too much depending on
The accidents of fortune to be thought
Worthy of him—I on this Armor look
As ſpoiles got from ſome conquer'd enemy,
His garments loſt by ſtealth, not from him took
By any force of man.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p:
She is in the right Nunckel, my brother Collonel
ſtole them, whilſt my ſquire and I ſcal'd the wals.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I thought 'twas ſome ſuch deſperate attempt;
Let me diſarme thee love, and ſee thy wounds.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Rare Artiſts! this Philter works wonders.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: He hath met with ſome cheat for Knights,
And the nails of whores for ſteel.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Let me wipe off the bloud, and thy poor ſervants too.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: I will not trouble you Miſtris, I uſe to heal ſuch ſleight wounds as this by waſhing them in mine own water.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: I had rather go in out of the cold.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Thou makeſt me bluſh unmanner'd fool:
Why doeſt not with more thankfulneſſe imbrace
The tender of her love?—Lewcippus have them
In, and ſee them once more cloth'd.
I can impute as much to youths irregularity
As others can: but if he leave not this,
My hate may ruine what my love hath built.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I hope your wiſdom Sir will look on this
But as an errour, which correcting age
May eaſily reform.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: —This is an ill ſign—I doubt he will ſpend all.

lg.l: I ſhall do much for your ſake Lady.
—Let's in and ſee him, though 'twere amiſs,
To make him mend, it is to laugh at this.

div.stage: Ex. om.

div.head: Actus Quartus. Scena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter the King in a night gown, two Pages with lights, one bearing uhe picture of Heroina, the other of Eurione, ſet down the light and pictures, and ex. Pages.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: BEe gone, and let me gaze my ſelf to marble here.
Oh I have loſt the quiet of my ſoul,
All peacefull harmony. My eyes have ſuckt
A ſubtill poiſon, and diſperſt it through
My ſouls oreflowing rivolet. Oh Heroina
I have defil'd thoſe noble thoughts in which
I ſhould have cloth'd the memory of this
—Fain would I ſmoother this proud flame—
—But vainly ſtrive—
It hath lay'd hold on reaſons battlements.
—This is Heroina's— Looks on her picture.
The ſame whoſe fair Idea untill now,
I only entertain'd within my thoughts—
And muſt I let this glorious angell flie
From the polluted temple?—I muſt
—Here lies a ſpell that charmes me Oopens Eurione's picture.
—What did I ſay—
Pardon thou fair commandreſſe of my ſoul,
I did blaſpheme—this ſacred beauty is
Fit for loves higheſt Altar, where my heart
If ſacrific'd dies in Enthean fire,
Pure as the Elements, when quinteſſene't
Into perfection ſhall communicate
To bodies glorified—
—Theſe bloudleſſe ſhadows hold no ſymmetry
In their proportion, this interiour orb
Sits like a ſmaller Planet near the Sun.
—I ſhould not thus ſharpen a Scorpions ſting,
If not already Baſilisk'd to death.
—But I like Atlas vainly ſtruggle to
O' • ethrow a world of fancy—I'm reſolv'd.
sp.stage: Knocks, enter Page, takes him a Letter.
sp.l: Convey this ſpeedily to Oroandes.
The cure is dangerous, but where the ſharp diſeaſe
Breaths nought but deſperation, 'tis in vain
Through reaſons Limbeck to extract our thoughts.
Mufi'd in clouds of ſin and ſhame I go
To grope for light, or ſink in endleſſe wo. Ex. King.

div.stage: Enter Vanlore leading in Theocrine.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be not too confident my Vanlore,
They're deſperate gameſters
That throw their whole ſtock at one trembling caſt.
If in this mornings progreſſe we are maskt,
Time ne'r will lend a beam to light us forth
Of ſorrows ſubtill labyrinth—ſhould thy plot
Crampt with prevention halt behind thy hopes,
And I be marryed to this wretch—we may
Go then aſide, and ſacrifice our tears,
Our fruitleſſe tears unto thoſe Gods for whom
We have prepared our holy vowes—but never
Muſt meet in warm imbraces.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Do not doubt
The powerfull influence of our ſtars—ſhould what
I have prepar'd to combate their deſign,
Be by ſome ſullen ſpie betrayed,—I have
Fitted a friend ordain'd for action in
This Comick Scene, whoſe ſword hath gliſter'd 'mongſt
A throng of braver enemies then they;
By whoſe aſſiſtance, if they durſt oppoſe,
He cut the cordage of that hand although
Before the Altar, that layes hold on thee.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would not have that ſilver feather'd dove,
On whoſe pure wings we firſt rais'd our affection,
Her yet immaculate pinnions dip in bloud.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Yet muſt we not
Tamely let Vultures prey upon our hearts.
I hear thy Father, Ceugh within.
And muſt betake my ſelf to canting.

div.stage: Enter Carlo, ſervant leading him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh—oh—oh!
Help me good Doctor:
Oh this tormenting Gout, my joints are rack'd.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Marke you Mounſieur—you muſt be—paeſant till my me-di-cine can operate.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh I can hold no longer, ſet me down ſoftly Geafery.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: And lay up de leg Sh-free—
Here on de Cuſhoone—ſo—no, eaſie now.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not much—not much—how now girl?
Haſt thou ſent to invite thy gheſts?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I have Sir, but doubt your want of health will much obſtruct their mirth.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We'l have the fewer girl, 'twill ſave charges.
I do not like theſe coſtly feaſts,
They but undo young couples—Oh my joints!
Doctor, we ſhall have your company.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Me be very ſorry, me cannot be your ſervant,
But de number of de patients dat call upon me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We ſhall excuſe you Sir, but could your time permit, you ſhould be rang'd with the beſt of our friends.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Me humbly thank you Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We will be free, though my husband be not Courtly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not Courtly ſaiſt, marry the better wench, it puts me in hope I ſhall not live to ſee thee want, the ſwaggering Gallant goes out like a ſnuff, when the conſtant houſekeeper gives the beſt light at laſt—Oh—oh—oh! my pain is intolerable—

I would not have him hearken to this paltry poetry, nor
viſit •• arlotry playhouſes. Let his imployments be to read the Statutes.—oh—'twill do him good—the knavery of a Lawyer, or the cunning of a Bankrout ſhall never undo him.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: And toſe as I have heard be diſeaſes Epidemical—but be de law de ſpeciall antidote.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis our laſt refuge, but in theſe parts not thoroughly proſecuted, I have now at the leaſt fifty ſuits depending, and many of them I know to be poor raſcals and not able to pay—oh now—now—And yet I can have no further recompence then throwing them in Gaole—Oh my knee!—where they ſhall lie till they rot, if they pay not.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Some Tradeſmen Mris. Theocrine
Deſire to ſpeak with you. Ex. The.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do not buy thy garments too gaudy,
Gold is better in thy purſe then on thy back.
Take example by thy aged father, Theocrine.
Oh now it tugs again—now—now!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Be of good comfort, it is but de acerbity of de humor—I will to my poiſon mixers, and prepare de richeſt ingredients.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I think an ointment of good Foot oyl were good,
It is cheap and eaſily got, I would not
Be at too much charges—lead me in
Geofry—oh!—farewell good Doctor—oh!
This double charges will undo me.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Thou ne'er wilt be ſo happy, wretched Miſer,
To have that file poliſh thy cankerd ſoul.
The generous ſpirits puniſhment would be
To thee the effects of mercy. Is Theocrine,
My virtuous Theocrine, deſcended from
So vile a Father? Sure her Mother was
Some Angell clothed in fleſh, that could not be
Corrupted with th' affinity of vice;
Elſe had the rudeneſſe of his nature planted
Some thornes within that Paradiſe, which now
The amorous Myrtles tender branches dreſſe
In ſuch ſoft lovely robes, her paſſions are
Sharpn'd with anger, but like thornes plac't
To guard thoſe roſes Virgin modeſty.
Nor can pale fear in her more refuge ſeek,
Then to improve the Lillies on her cheek.

div.stage: Enter Theocrine.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come follow me Vanlore,
I have prepar'd thy habit—let's haſten. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Buff. Godg. Creon, Lewcip.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Fie, fie!
Not ready yet, and to be a Bridegroom ere break of day?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: I cannot tie my bond-ſtrings.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Aſſiſt him Gudgeon—S-death! what doeſt gape for?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: Cham't thorowly awak'd yet, chad rather
Be at whome again, a keeping of Sheep,
There chad time to fetch out my full ſleep,
Here cham tottered up all hours of the night.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Why, thou doeſt not grumble Raſcall, give me—come, p • x on thy gouty fingers, they are fitter to tie ſacks—

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter for your frumps:
sp.p: Chon't be thus abuſed long, chill get me home, and be a paultry Servingman no longer, to lick trenchers and live upon ſcraps.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Why, how now ſlave, wert thou ever thus fine before?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Yes in a pranked ſuit, 'tis much credit ſure, e'n as much as the ſlit in our hawked Bullocks ear, or a mark in the ſide of a Sheep.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Come Tutor, now come help me truſſe my points, Chwas never thus troubled with harneſſing my ſelf before, and this be the fruit of marriage, I will marry no more yet in haſt. If my Nunckel had been a man as other men be, he might ha marryed her his ſelf, and ha ſaved me this labour, but no matter Gudgeon, we'l have about at trull-me-dems when the Parſon hath done.

div.stage: Enter Arratus.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: I to my grief have heard all this.
Unmaner'd ſlave! are theſe the fruits of all
My ill beſtowed expenſes? I ſee it lies not
I'th power of art to poliſh thee, I have
Ranſack'd the City for the choieſt wits,
They rackt invention to improve thy knowledge,
And yet thou ſtill remainſt a ſenſleſſe block.
—Pox on your ugly looks—you ſleepiſh clown,
Pull up thy ſpirits—or by heaven— Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Gud
sp.l: Maſter, give the teſty old fool a clowt o'th car.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: What, art thou barking connſell to him?
Never were there ſuch a couple of whelpes
Harl'd together, hell take you both for muddy ſlaves;
He rather leave my revenues in the wals of a Hoſpitall,
Or build Temples for the next Faction to pull down,
Then beſtow it on ſuch a puppy.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: 'T will become your diſcretion, Sir, to ſmother
Your anger for the preſent, let this dayes
Buſineſſe be paſt over ere you nouriſh the flame;
Then if you ſee no reformation, we ſhall not
Counſell to ought your judgment approves not of.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Should you ſo untimely withdraw your love,
His diſgrace would reflect on your reputation.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: You ſhall prevail for this once, come Sirrah
—See thy behaviour redeem thy credit
—Or thou art loſt—

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: —Loſt! hey—'tis no matter and we were
Both loſt, ſo we could find ſome of our old
Mates again—Ich can't abide theſe Courtnowles. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Zanna. leading Glori. Oroandes Eurione.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Muſt we part here?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yes there are ſome ceremonies yet to come
—Ere you enter farther—

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: —To morrow night
No Cherubin will guard the gates that lead
Unto our blisful thrones, theſe Ivory temples
Will dedicated both to Janus ſtand
Open in all the Civill wars of love.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: How Oroandes—thou art wanton friend,
We yet are cloth'd in thoughts as pure and white
As new created Veſtals, ſuch diſcourſe
Will not be harmony—when fetter'd in
Your bridall beds, we willing captives lie.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Nor diſcord my Eurione—the modeſt bluſh
Corals the Virgin cheek no longer then
The trecherous light betrayes her to the view
Of the delighted Paranymphs.
The curtain'd bed preſents unknown delights
Cloth'd in unpractic't nature, which improv'd
By loves aſſimilating virtue warmes
The unform'd embryo into full blown joy.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What ſhall I call this, experimental or imaginary?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Thy virtue beſt knows what—

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I ſee my Lord the active wars afford
Sometime to melt in paſſive thoughts, your ſteel
Soft love may poliſh to a looking glaſſe.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Yes, and work the waving plume into a fan.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The ſtubborn helmet into lawn, and ſtrew
Bodkins and pins for rapiers round their beds.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Why, Ladies—though we have been
Immur'd in ſteel, we are no Cyclopes yet,
Our joints are ſupple, though not weak as thoſe
Whoſe knees are oftner to his Miſtris bowed
Then to his God, who meaſures out his life
In wanton Galliards, and a fidleſtick
Knows better how to handle then a ſword,
No ſtand of pikes their briſtled ſquadrons place
About our chins, nor are our lips hedg'd in
With quickſet beards which thatch a Scythians face.
The Souldier when he'th ſtew'd his bowels in
The bloud, and ſweat of enemies, is then
Moſt fit to kiſſe the balmy lips of peace;
His freſh and luſty appetite digeſts
What glutted Courtiers ſurfet on, and makes
They labour his refreſhing exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: We cannot doubt the ſoftneſſe your limbs,
As long as flints will break on feather beds.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Thy active wit my Glorianda ſports
In our rude fancies deſerts.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Let her friend, to morrow night ſhe muſt
Impal'd within the narrow circle of
Thy armes bebarr'd that liberty, and then
Her world of Virgin thoughts will all conclude
In the poſſeſſion of Elyzium,
Her Lillies and thy Lawrell both will be
Oretopt by Cupids Myrtles. The Phoenix
And warlike Eagle to a wilderneſſe
Untrod by fancies future ſteps may flie,
Whilſt Venus D • ves are harbour'd in your breſts.

div.stage: Enter a Page.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: —My Lord—

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: To me!—thy buſineſſe. Gives him a Letter.
From his Majeſty.
It nought contains but what muſt be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: I ſhall return that anſwer Sir. Ex Pag.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: They muſt not ſee this, it may contain
News that may ruffle all their calm delights.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What was this fellowes buſineſſe Oroandes?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: The King hath ſent for me. Go virgin friends,
This night lie ſhivering in your native ice,
The blooming ſpring approaches, which muſt change
Your ſnow to beds of roſes—goodnight
—Bleſt Angels claſp their wings about your beds.

div.stage: Ex. Oro.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Come—Ile only wait you to your Chamber door,
And there—leave my beſt wiſhes to attend you further.

div.stage: Ex ſeverally.
Enter the Prieſt of Hymen, two Maids leading Buffonie, Creon and Lewcippus leading Theocrine, Carlo born in a chair, Arratus with lights and attendants.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Carry me gently—oh that my pain ſhould ſo vex me at this good time!

div.stage: Being come to the middle of the Stage, the candles begin to wax out, flaſhes of light within the curtain, Vanlore in manner of a ghoſt appears, and ſuddenly draws back within the curtain.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: What prodigies are theſe?

sp.speaker: (Arr.)
sp.p: The light appears again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It is ſome ſpectrum.

sp.speaker: (Buf.)
sp.p: I hope the Devill wo' not forbid the banes.

div.stage: He appears again, at which the bearers letting fall Carlo's chair, • un hastily forth all but Carlo, who lies ſprawling on the ground, to him enters one diſguized in a dreadfull ſhape repreſenting the Devill.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: —Prepare—prepare
I come to bear
Thy body where
No eye ſhall ere
Behold thee more, but thoſe that ſhare
With thee in everlaſting care.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: —Oh!—Oh!—I cannot riſe,
Some good body ſave me from the ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Come—come away,
Hell hates delay,
I ſent the day,
And dare not ſtay,
Leſt light my ugly form betray,
Ghoſts may not ſee what mortals may.
Be gone foul fiend, there are ſome ſaving drops
Of mercy yet hang over him and ſtops
Thy eager haſt.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Oh do not waſt
Thy time i'th' air, heaven his eternall doom
Hath ſeal'd with Orphanes bloud, but will no room
For ſuch dam'd ſouls admit,
Thou art call'd up to ſit
Circl'd with glory 'mongſt the blisful thrones,
But he caſt down, down, where in hollow groans
His ſins ſhall ſtill complain.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Tears will waſh off their ſtain,
There needs no flames to purge them Live—live then
But only to repent on earth—which when
Perform'd, come reſt with me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where art? oh let me ſee.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That is not in my power to grant—to thin
Unbodied aire I am reſolv'd, which in
This region only hovers
Till time and fate diſcovers
What will become of thee.

sp.speaker: Dev
sp.l: What but to go
Wi • h me where flouds of flaming ſulphur flow,
Through dark and ſouty caves,
Where endleſſe madneſſe raves,
Where living flame in everlaſting night
Still dying burns, but burning gives no light?
The buſie Furies there
His reſtleſſe bed prepare
Of molten gold ſpread o're with burning flakes,
Curtain'd with horror, and begirt with Snakes.
Then ceaſe, and haſt unto
Thoſe white ſouls that have flew
Above my reach, which I have only power
To envy not to hurt.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But can the hour
Not be a while prolong'd?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Then deſtiny were wrong'd.

div.stage: Shaking his chains he runs towards him, at which enter the Prieſt in his pontificall ornaments, as he begins to read, the Devill roaring runs forth.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I thought thou durſt not ſtand-to encounter with So brave an enemy as this.

div.stage: A noiſe within, at which Carlo riſing runs halting forth. Ex. Prieſt.
Enter Vanlore, Theocrine, and two Bandeets.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: They're gone—and too much frighted to return in haſt.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Our plot hath equall to our wiſhes thriv'd.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I am indebted—brave Bandeets to you,
But will requite it in the like attempt
When ere occaſion ſhall require my aid.

sp.speaker: 1 Ban.
sp.l: We are ſo much your creatures Sir, that tis
The child of duty, when our gratitude
Offers all ſervice to ſo loved a maſter.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Time will admit but ſmall commerce of words,
My actions ſtill ſhall ſpeak me yours—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Dear Vanlore let's be gone;
They will purſue as ſoon as they've collected
Their yet unrallied ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Thou art the loadſtone Theocrine, by whoſe
Attractive power the Compaſſe of my thoughts
Directed by thy wit, their Needle, ſteers
My almoſt Shipwrackt hopes, into a ſafe
And quiet harbor of content. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Oroandes alone reading a note.

lg.l: —The hour five—the place the plain beneath the
Hermits rock.
I have not miſt in either circumſtance,
Unleſſe my haſte anticipated time—it yet is not full five
—The morning hath not loſt her virgin bluſh
Nor ſtep, but mine ſoild the earths tinſel'd robe.
—How full of heaven this ſolitude appears,
This healthful comfort of the happy ſwain,
Who from his hard, but peacefull bed rous'd up
In's morning exerciſe ſaluted is
By a full quire of feather'd Choriſters
Wedding their notes to the inamour'd air.
Here Nature in her unaffected dreſſe,
Plaited with vallies and imboſt with hils,
Enchac't with ſilver ſtreams, and fring'd with woods,
Sits lovely in her native ruſſet, whilſt
Lame Art to hide her known deformitie
With painting ſurfets each diſcerning eie.

div.stage: Enter the King diſguized.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: 'Tis he, but ſtrangely chang'd.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Oroandes, you're now a loyal Subject.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: All my ambition ne'r flew higher Sir,
Then in that region of your thoughts to thrive.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: There it was grown to full maturity
Ere thou wroteſt man, my Oroandes, but I muſt
Like wanton Nero either ruine all
The glorious ſtructure of thy hopes, or live
Impriſon'd in thy loyalty, thy life
Till now my ſtrongeſt fortreſſe is become
The fatall engine of my ruine.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: —Heaven—what have I done to merit this?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Nothing but been too virtuous, and by that
Center'd affections, which I muſt remove
Or ſhake thee into Chaos.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: This language blaſts me, ſure I have no ſin
Ponderous enough to boy your vengeance up
Unto this dangerous height. Did I but think
One Viper lodg'd in my remoteſt thought,
I'd tear each fiber of my heart to find
The monſter forth, and in my bloud imbalm'd
Throw it as far as lifes ſhort ſpan can reach.
But heaven my witneſſe is, no flame of zeal
But hath been yours i'th ſecond magnitude,
My vowes of kin to thoſe I paid the gods,
My prayers, but love, and duty, fir'd into
A holy Calenture. Yet if all this
Like a ſmall Stars kind influence govern'd by
A regall Planets croſſe aſpects, muſt drop
Its fading beams into that houſe of death
Your fierce deſtructive anger, let me ſhew
The latitude of my obedience, in
Dying at the command of him for whom
I only wiſh to live. Did all my friends
Look on the object through their tears, the ghoſt
Of my dead Mother, capable of grief
As of eternity, and yet clothed in
Humanities moſt frail affections, all
Thoſe rivolets of ſorrow ſhould not waſh
The ſanguin ſtain of my reſolves, ſo they
If executed could procure a calm
In this high tempeſt of your ſoul.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thy virtue fathomes not my depth of guilt,
Such a prevention of my anger would
Only exchange the active paſſion for
Sorrow as inſupportable; thoſe characters
Which muſt unfold the ſables of my ſoul
Are in dark Hieroglyphicks hid, through which
Thy ſtrength of judgment cannot pierce.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: You ſpeak in miſty wonders, Sir, ſuch as lead
My apprehenſion into wilde Meanders.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: This will unriddle all our doubts—draw.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Againſt my Soveraign! an act ſo wicked would
Re • ort the guilty ſteel into my breaſt.
Fear never yet marbled a cowards bloud
More then obedience mine, that breath hath lockt
In ice the panting channels of my heart,
No ſpirits dare from their cold center move.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will you deny—when I command?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Pardon me royall Sir; had ſuch a voice
Legitimated my attempts, I had
Not paus'd at the incounter of a danger
Horrid as all the wars oth' elements,
When ruffl'd into ſtormes could preſent;
I would beſtride a cloud with lightning charg'd,
In's ſull carreer affront a thunderboult,
Leap through the clefts of earthquakes, or attempt
To prop the ruins of a falling rock,
Yet count all this my happineſſe, ſo I
Met death in the white robes of loyalty.
But to encounter ſuch a ghaſtly foe
In the black ſhadow of Rebellion, ſhakes
The ſtrongeſt pillars of my ſoul. You are my King,
My King—whoſe frowns ſhould be
More dreadfull to me, then oraculous truths
When threatning ſudden ruine; your ſacred perſon
Is circl'd with divinity, which without reverence
To touch is ſacriledge, to look on ſin
Unleſſe each glance is uſher'd with a prayer.
Kings are but living / temples, wherein is
As in the Nations center, the chief ſeat
Of their protecting God, and ſhall I then
Pollute my hands in bloud, whoſe every drop
Would ſwell my Countreys tears into a floud?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Are my attempts priz'd at ſo cheap a rate?
Wears not my ſword a danger on its point
As well as thine?—draw—or I ſhall conclude
'Tis fear, not loyalty, that charmes thy hand.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: This ſtirs my bloud—were you a private man
That only had his better genius to
Protect him, though allied to me by all
The ties of Nature and of friendſhip, yet
Being thus far urged, our Swords long ſince ſhould have
Made known whoſe Stars the brighter influence had.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I have unfetter'd all thoſe legall bondes—draw,
For thy denying now but ſleights my power.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Then—ſince there's no evaſion, Or. draws.
Witneſſe ye Gods—my inocence is wrong'd.
—But gratious Sir— Kneels.
Before I fall—or ſtand, leſſe fortunate
To ſee you overthrow, oh let me know
What fate,—what cruell fate hath rob'd me of
The treaſures of your love: I never yet
Sullied my ſoul with any thought that might
Deſerve your hate, heaven is my faithful witneſſe
I harbour none of you, but ſuch as are
More full of zeal then thoſe pure orizons,
Which martyr'd Saints mix with their dying groans.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And muſt ſuch goodneſſe die!—know noble youth,
I am ſo far from calling it deſert
In thee, that hath unſheathed my ſword, that in
This midnight ſtorm of fancy, I can ſhead
Some drops of pity too, pity to change
So true a ſubject for a treacherous gheſt.
I come not raſhly to attempt thy life,
But long have ſtrugl'd with my hot deſires,
Stood fiery trials of temptations, which
Have ſublimated reaſon till it's grown
Too volatile to be contain'd within
My brain, that overheated Crucible.
I am diſeas'd, and know no way to health
But through a deluge of thy bloud.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: There needs not then this ſtorm to break down
The bayes that verge the crimſon ſea—this ſtroke
Shall open all the ſluces of my bloud.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Hold—or elſe thou rob'ſt me of my fixt reſolves.
—There is a cauſe—
Commands me die in the attempt, or kill thee.

sp.speaker: Gro.
sp.l: Dear Sir, reveal it—
That ere I fall my penitential tears
May from that leprous crime expunge my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Alas brave youth, thy innocence needs not
The layer of a tear, thy candid thoughts
White as the robes of Angels are, but mine
The dreſſe of Devils, I that ſhould protect
Am come to rob my beſt of ſubjects, to rob
Thee of thy deareſt treaſure; I know thy love
To fair Eurione inſeparable
As goodneſſe from a deity—yet muſt
Deprive thee of this darling of thy ſoul.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: With pardon, royall Sir, I cannot think
The Cyprian Princeſſe is ſo ſoon forgot,
With whom compar'd, my poor Eurione
Though bright to me, to more diſcerning eyes
Shine dim as the pale Moon when ſhe lets fall
Through a dark grove her melancholy beams.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Dorſt thou affect her, yet diſpraiſe a beauty
That in its orb contracts divinity?
This prophanation, what had elſe been ſin
Will render meritorious—guard thy ſelf.

div.stage: They fight, Antellus wounded.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: —Hah—thou bleedeſt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Oh but too ſlowly—if your wound admits
No other medicine, this will neer be balm.

div.stage: Fight again, the King wounde.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: I doubt that thruſt—

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: It was a gentle one, and hath concluded
The buſineſſe that we met for.
Now we are friends again; friends till death. Fals.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Oh do not faint,
Call up your ſpirits Sir, there yet is hopes of life.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: None—my vitall powers fail—they're heavy leads,
My eyes are bowing to eternall night,
My heart beats thick alarmes, yet can rally
No troops of ſcattered ſpirits—oh—oh!—I faint.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: And I grow wilde with horror, wilder then
A flame provoked by angry winds.
—What ſhall I do? or whither flie,
To leave behind me this purſuing guilt?

div.stage: A noiſe within.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: —Oh—oh—be gone—be gone Oroandes.
Some company draws neer.
Mayſt thou live long and happy in the imbraces
Of her, whom I unjuſtly ſtrove to have.
My dying wiſhes waits upon your joyes.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Angels attend your lateſt hour, I go
From hence, but to my everlaſting wo. Ex. Oroandes.

div.stage: Enter four Bandeets.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: S-death! Ile not looſe my ſhare.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: Nor I, by heaven, although I ſearch
For what's my own through my oppoſers bloud.

sp.speaker: 3. Ban.
sp.l: Swounds! what d'ee quarrel for trifles?
Pox on you for covetous Raſcals, take all mine.

sp.speaker: 4. Ban.
sp.l: And mine too, ſo you will be content.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Another prize, the ſpoil of this will reconcile us.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.p: He bleeds—Sh-ho—he ſtirs not, let's ſtrip him.

sp.speaker: 3. Ban.
sp.l: There's life in him—let's bear him off.
sp.p:
I have heard the captive Lady ſpeak of a pretious Cordial
ſhe hath, if it recover him, his ranſome may be better worth then theſe gaudy clothes—

sp.speaker: 4. Ban.
sp.l: Here, lend your hands.

div.stage: They lay the body on a Cloke, and ex.
Enter Buff. and Gudg.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Oh Gudgeon we are undone, there is no recovering of her—what ſhall I do for another wife?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: Shall I let her cry Maſter?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Ah, do good carefull ſervant, ſome of theſe honeſt people may chance to know of her, aloud good Gudgeon.

div.stage: Mounts on a ſtool.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: —Oh yes—oh yes—oh yes
If any man—in City—Town—or Countrey,
Can tell any tidings of a ſtrayed Lady.

div.stage: Enter Arratus and Carlo.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: What's this? A hobby-horſe dance?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Oh no Sir—good Nunckel be quiet—
My man Gudgeon is only making known my loſſe.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Is this thy grief, unpoliſht clown?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Why ſhould I cry my ſelf as long as I had a man?

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Thou art a ſcandall which will ever ſtick
Like a corroding cancer on my name
—Be gone— Kicks him.
Back to thy ruſtick father, and there ſpend
Thy time 'mongſt beaſts leſſe ſavage then thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Why then farewel, a turd for all ſuch Nunckels.
Come Gudgeon we'l een go home to plow again.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Ay, and whiſtle better tunes then ere we learn'd at Court. Ex. Buff. and Gudg.

div.stage: Enter a Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh ſave me brother,
Here comes the ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: My Lord Arratus, you are ſuddenly expected at the Court.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Why good friend?—what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: The King and my Lord Oroandes are miſſing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
How! loſt!—I hope my daughters meſſenger hath not tranſported them, was it a ghoſt carryed them away
friend? ſpeak man—I hear them ſtill.

sp.speaker: M • ſſ.
sp.l: I come not to jeſt Sir, my Lord, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Arr
sp.l: I will follow thee—how am I perplext?
Come brother I will ſee you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We will not go through the Gallery,
The place ſmels of Brimſtone. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Zannazarro, Glorianda, and Eurione.

sp.speaker: Zan
sp.l: How ſad a change is this! this morning was
Appointed for more joyfull enter views.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: When laſt nights ſlumbers rob'd our wakeful hopes
Of the delitious births of fancy, 'twas
With fairer promiſes, elſe our cloſed eyes
Had not been then m • de floudgates to theſe tears.
—Poor Eurione, I fain would comfort thee,
But my own griefs make me a ſtranger to
—That balmy language.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Dear Siſter—thy paſſions are too violent,
The meſſengers are not yet all return'd,
Not have we ſpoke with Arratus, ſome of which
—May happily bring news of them.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: They may Eurione, ſtifle thy paſſions untill then.

div.stage: Enter Arratus.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: My Lord, you either come to ſhare in grief
With us, or eaſe ours by ſome bleſt diſcovery.
—You've heard what royal mineral let flie this damp.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Our Soveraign's loſt.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Too ſad a truth.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: My largeſt intelligence lies within the wals of the
City, and there he hath not been yet heard of.
Is none with him my Lord?.—

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Yes, Oroandes—

sp.speaker: Arrr.
sp.l: I will go have the City ſearcht.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: That hath already proved a fruitleſſe labour.
Vain as the glimmerings of our hope, they're gone
Beyond the reach of our induſtrious care,
Some cruell fate hath laid an ambuſh to
Betray the ſtrength of all our joyes in them.

div.stage: Enter a Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Here comes our laſt of hopes, ſpeak thy ſucceſſe.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Not good my Lord, we've traverſt all the fields
That circle loſty Erix, and yet ſeen
No chearfull beam of wiſht intelligence,
We le • t no traveller unaskt, no Cottage lay
So unfrequented but we found it out,
And into ſtrict examination took
Its ruſtick honour. Yet our journey was
Oft by the dangerous excurſions of
Troops of Bandeets obſtructed, ſafe from whom
Our ſpeed not ſtrength convey'd us, all we found
Worthy to fix an obſervation, was
A place beneath the Hermits rock, which ſtained
With ſtore of bloud, did by that bluſh confeſſe
So late a guilt, no cloud had ſince 'twas ſhed
Dropt tears enough to waſh it off, we ſearcht,
The purple graſſe, but no veſtigia found,
'Leſs this may do it, to inform us whence it came.

div.stage: Shews a bloudy handkerchief which they finde to be the Kings.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Oh my Prophettique fears!

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Our Sorrows are confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: They are, in bloudy characters.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: I will go and ſecure the Cittadel, and cry treaſon▪

div.stage: Ex. Arratus.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: —Sorrow outgrowes all my reſolves.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: And my heart rents with this divided grief.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: This is an act of theſe untamed Bandeets,
Theſe plagues of Sicily, but if the force
Of Syracuſe can bay their power, we'l have
Their heads to build a temple ore his grave.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth Act.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: The King led in by a Bandeet, Heroina preparing to dreſſe him.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I've now got ſtrength enough to render thanks
Unto the fair preſerver of my life.
—Were is ſhe Sir?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Here, ready to ſecond my firſt weak indevours.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: They then were ſtrengthen'd by ſome power above
The common reach of art, my weakneſſe elſe
Had yet confin'd me to my ſickly bed.

div.stage: He ſits whilſt ſhe dreſſes him.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Let me aſſiſt you Lady—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Your change of colour argues faintneſſe Sir,
This will recall your ſpirits— Gives him a Cordial.
D'ee feel no alteration?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Yes my ſpirits ſtir, as if they would ſhake off
The ſluggiſh weight of weakneſſe, I am grown
Active as if the vigorous ſtrength of youth
And health were wedded in my heart, my bloud
Runs as it ſcorn'd to be confin'd within
The channels of my veins, yet is allayed
By th'even temper of my ſoul. Sure this
Rare Cordiall was ſome deities rich gift.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The fitter to be given to thoſe they love,
For ſuch you are, elſe my poor medicines had
Ne're thus effected miracles.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Am I no longer uſeful here? if not,
My buſineſſe cals me hence.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sir I ſhould wrong your curteſie to draw
You from the front of time, if ought that may
Concern your ſelf commands you hence.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Then I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My thanks attend you Sir. Ex. Band.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How much in every turning of the • ie
Doth he reſemble my heroick love? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You're ſad ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I have a cauſe, and ſuch a one that did
You know, your goodneſſe would commiſerate
My wretched fortune.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Reveal it Lady, I perhaps may be
Inabled then to give your Cordials back
In ſome ſuch curteſie as may deſerve
To be a thankfull handmaid unto yours.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I was reſolv'd to weep away my time
In private ſorrow, but diſcovery can
Not aggravate my woe, beſides I may
Venture to lodge a ſecret, where I have found
Such temperate virtues the ſouls portals bar,
Ile only with this queſtion uſher in
My own diſcovery, • s Sicily your place
Of birth or not?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: It is, and breeding both.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Ile not demand what were the Parentage
Where I find virtues plant Nobility,
Yet would be loath to a Plebeian breaſt
To truſt what I muſt now divulge.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You may be confident, I am a Gentleman
As well by birth as education Lady.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I do preſume it Sir, and therefore wiſh,
Of all I now remain amongſt to be
Known unto you alone—
You never had relation to the Court?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: There was my breeding.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Neer the perſon of the King?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: One of his Bed-chamber, and 'tis no boaſt
To ſay as well belov'd of him as any,
There being in the opinion of the Court
A neer reſemblance of our looks.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Then ſure my name is not a ſtranger to you,
Have you not heard of the Cyprian Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The beauteous Heroina.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The wretched Heroina, ſuch I'm ſure
Is my condition in my preſent ſtate.

sp.speaker: Kin
sp.l: Pardon this child of ignorance, my rude Kneels.
And unbecoming boldneſſe.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Riſe Sir, we are companions yet,
And hope we ſhall be, till your royall Maſter
Poſſeſſe, what was long ſince intended his;
By what diſaſter I was caſt upon
This dreadfull precipice of danger, as
We are withdrawing Ile relate, but not
To tempt a danger ſtay you longer here.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Your care can have no ſatisfaction but
A loyall ſervants prayers. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Oroandes and a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Gro.
sp.l: Not find the body ſayſt?—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: No Sir—yet by the large effuſion of his bloud
Had a too ſad aſſurance of the place,
Some Mountaineers have certainly c • nveyed
His body thence to burial; thoſe bloudy characters
Are arguments of no leſſe ill then death.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: —Then I am loſt eternally—loſt to all
That bears a ſhew of goodneſſe, heaven, and earth
Will both ſtrive to forget they ever knew
A ſoul deſorm'd with wickedneſſe like mine.
—My feveriſh ſins dry up the dews of mercy
In their deſcent, and blaſt all vertue that
Approaches neer me, I ſhall never find
A Saint in heaven, or Fiend on earth but will,
As a dire prodigy, created to
Scatter infection through the world, forſake
My ha • ed company, as fit to mix
With none but the ſociety of Devils.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Sir I wiſh I in ought • lie could ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: I thank thee friend— Ex Surgeon.
—Heaven—
What an unweildy monſter am I grown
Since by this act ſwel'd to a regicide—
—Oh my accurſed ſtars that only lent
Your influence to light me to damnation,
Not all my penitential tears will ere
Waſh off the ſpots from my ſtain'd ſoul, this gangren
Is cur'd by no Lixivium but of bloud.
My heart is lodg'd within a bed of Snakes
Such as old fancies arm'd the Furies with.
Conſcience waits on me like the frighting ſhades
Of ghoſts when gaſtly meſſengers of death.
My thoughts are but the inforc't retreats
Of tortut'd reaſon to a troubled fancy.
—Hah!—am I ſurprized—

div.stage: Enter Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Sir not by me, I only finding that
You were much troubled at this accident,
Am come to lend you my aſſiſtance in
Concealing of your perſon, untill by
The mediation of your friends you may
Open theſe harſh obſtructions of your fate.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: This is a curteſie I never merited
Either from heaven, or thee their meſſenger.
My hopes are yet not wholly ruin'd, I will
Along with thee, and in ſome dark diſguiſe
Expect the clouded raies of better things.

div.stage: Ex. Sur. and Oroandes.
Enter Vanlore, Theocrine, and Bandeets.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Now Theocrine I boldly may ingage
My promiſe for thy ſafety, we are paſt
All habitable places—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Were not thy company my beſt ſecurity,
This deſerts wilde inhabitants would fright
Me more then all my fathers Scouts, to whom
Without a bluſh my innocence would dare
Diſrobe my actions, now I fear no fate
So ſad as the preventing my deſires.

lg.l: Thou art the joy and comfort of my life;
More chearfull then the ſuns ſociety
To winter ſtarved Scythians;—Come my Love
This bed of Violets courts us to repoſe.
Now,—now within the circle of my armes
I graſp a gem, by me more prized then all
The worlds five zones imbraces, now we live
I' • h' upper ſphere of fancy, and ſpin out
The eveneſt threeds of all our mortall web.
Theſe are the ſugr'd minutes of our lives,
The balmy drops that cure the minds ſad wounds.
Since man loſt Paradiſe, he knew no place
To emblem heaven, but in a womans face.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why thou art wanton friend, this is diſcourſe
For Love that hath not out-grown infancy,
Ours now is too mature—

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nor ever will, when we are both grown old,
Thy poliſht ivory furrowed o'er with age
In ſilver robes on beauties ruines plac't
Our mutuall wonder ſtill ſhall laſt, but I
Muſt binde up all the gaudy flowers of love
In threeds of admiration, no epithites
Such fragrant virtues ſeparated from
The generall name of good, can ere again
Pick out and bind them in due prayſes up.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I can be well content to hear thee talk
On any argument, but a leſſe pleaſing
Thou couldſt not well have taken. Enter a Bandeet.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: S-death! Captain, what d'ee mean?
This is no place of ſafety, the wayes are all beſet
With troops of horſe, our Scouts beat in from all parts
Wounded and bloudy, if we all betake not our ſelves
To our armes we are loſt in an inſtant.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Oh prithy Vanlore haſten hence.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I only fear thy ſafety. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter two Bandeets wounded.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: S death! we muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: Tis not our uſe to run.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Pox on't, the oddes is unreaſonable.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.p: Swounds, I think they have horſt all the Carters in the Countrey, the thick skin'd rogues my Rapier could hardly pierce them.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.p: But theirs pierc't us, I have a wound here yawnes like a Dragon—let's haſten to a Surgeon.

div.stage: Enter a Bandeet bleeding and fals.

sp.speaker: 3. Ban.
sp.l: Hell periſh all the ſlaves,
I'm kill'd by a ruſtick dog.
And what torments me moſt, fall unreveng'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.p: Poor Brother we would help thee, but want it our ſelves.

sp.speaker: 3. Ban.
sp.l: Yet bear me from the villains, and if your time
Permits, bury me like a Souldier, I was born
Of noble parentage, but drove by want
To theſe unlawfull courſes, and have this,
This for my puniſhment— One hollowes within.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: Hark—Swounds, we ſhall be ſurpriz'd
Here right ere long—

div.stage: They bear off him that fell, and ex. om.
Enter Heroina alone.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What deſperate wretches do I live amongſt?
Terror allarums them from every ſide,
Their Scouts bring no intelligence but death
Approaching at their backs, and yet
They bathe in riot, and with bloudy oathes
Stab heaven betwixt each word they ſpeak, their prayers
Are only for damnation, though they breath
Their ſouls forth with that fearful wiſh.

div.stage: Enter a Bandeet drunk.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: —Dam me—A ſhort life and a merry.
Swounds if we die—we die—let's be
Merry whilſt we live—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I tremble at this Villains ſight. Offers to go forth.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Whether now Doxie—S-death! you
Whore come hither—Pox on your ſqueamiſh face,
Lie down—or Ile cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You will not offer to abuſe me thus.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Dam me, Ile do'c, and thou wert my ſiſter,
Thy puling ſhall not ſave thee.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Upon my knees I beg thee not to touch me.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Thou wilt be heard better lying upon thy back.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thou knoweſt not whom thou injureſt;
—I am a Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: The better, then the boy I beget will be noble
By the Mothers ſide—Swounds, will you not bend?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Is none more civill near?

div.stage: Enter the King.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What villany is this,—
Forbear unhallowed ſlave, Snatches forth the Bandeets ſword.
This weapon ſhall revenge her if thou durſt
Abuſe her with the leaſt uncivil touch.

div.stage: Enter two Bandeets.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Swounds, help me here,
This Raſcall hath got my ſword.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: Dares the thawed ſnake to ſting?
Deliver him his ſword—

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will, ſo you will promiſe he ſhall uſe
It not to force reſiſtleſſe womens honour,
As late he did attempt this noble Virgins,
And if by me not timely reſcued had
Made it the prize of his oremaſtering ſtrength.

sp.speaker: 3. Ban.
sp.l: Muſt you Sir make conditions? They both draw and lay at him.

div.stage: Whilſt they are fighting, enter Vanlore and Theocrine.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: What is the cauſe of this?
Sheath your Swords, that man
That dares proffer another blow,
Forfeits his life for tribute to my ſword.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: This was a timely reſcue, and hath by
The fair redemption of my honour, more
Then ſatisfied all thoſe arrears, your life
D'd ſtand ingag'd in to my uſefull art.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The brighteſt ſtars that rule my fate did light
Me to the bleſt imployment, but had all
Set ere their influence had attain'd its end,
Had not this Gentlemans aſſiſtance lent
New vigour to their fading beams.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe a debt of thanks to him,
Which if irregular opinion prove
No enemy to his own ſafety, ſhall
Be ſuddenly diſcharg'd—You may perceive Sir
How black a ſtorm waits on the lives of all
Your wilde aſſociates, wherefore if you have
An overſwaying power amongſt them, chuſe
The now preſented opportunity
To free you from all future fears, which thus
Ile light you to, draw up your company,
And let thoſe perſecutors of my honour be
My convoy to the Court, you'l find a Prince
To be intreated, when your advocate
Bears Heroinaes name.

div.stage: Vanlore kneels.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Pardon me beſt of women, and impute
My rudeneſſe, to my ignorance,
If any ſervice can extenuate
Crimes of ſuch monſtrous growth, our blouds ſhall pay
The forfeit of our diſobedience, in
The not performing it.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Your hopes of ſafety prompts me to believe.
—Come Sir—you ſhall attend us to the Court.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am your vaſſal Madam, proud to have
Such a command to uſher my deſires. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Oroandes alone in the habit of a Forreſter.

sp.speaker: Oro.

lg.l: —Not yet—not yet at quiet—no diſguiſe
Is dark enough to curtain o'er my guilt,
Pale as the ghaſtly looks of men condemn'd
It ſits upon my Conſcience. I ſee there is
No place affords that ſoul a ſafe retreat
That is purſued by a ſharp-ſented ſin.
The proſperous murtherer that hath clothed his guilt
In royall Ermins, all thoſe furs of ſtate
Cannot preſerve from trembling, he looks on
Dejected wretches, as aſſaſinates,
And each petition for a ponyard fears.
—Yet theſe are more ſecure then I, they may
Pretend to merit in their wickedneſſe,
And call their crimes the cure of ſickly ſtates;
But I am left no refuge, leſſe to know
The depth of horror can no further go.
—Alas poor virtue, all thy white wing'd zeal
Is wrought into a bed of ſables, ſince
Leaving thy heavenly dictates I betrayed
My ſelf unto theſe ſooty gards of hell,
Whoſe black inhabitants already call
Me one of their ſociety;—my eyes
Are grown more killing then the Baſilisks,
And each vein fill'd with poiſon, ſince theſe hands,
Theſe curſed hands were ſtained with royal bloud.
—Hah—all this is true—
But do I want more deſperation yet?
Are there not fiends enough now waiting on me
To guide my trembling hand untill it reach
The center of my life?— Draws a ſword from behind the curtain.
This fatall weapon ſlew my Prince
—This was his bloud that ſtains it,—
The bloud that warm'd thoſe browes a crown imbrac't
—Let forth by me t'embalm the earth, and in
Warm vapors ſpend the pretious breath of life,
Which mounting upwards ſent perſumes to heaven;—
—But now thou muſt be dipt in that which will
Leave a perpetual ruſt upon thy ſteel
More fretting then a canker.—blaſt all that near it grows,
And as it cools infect the ambient air
With blaſts more deadly then the ſteams of hell—
—How it pants to come forth!—

sp.stage: Sets the Sword to his breaſt.

lg.l: —Hah!—ſomething ſtayes my hand
My better Angel ſure hath left me quite
—How e'er I will not do it,
Although that every blaſt of air I draw
Be more tormenting then the gaſps of death.—
—No, I will live—live till diſvellop'd guilt
Makes me a publick ſpectacle of hate—and then
Fall with my ſins about me, when each tongue
Adds to their ponderous weight a full mouthed curſe.
—The ſubtill ſpirits, that like lightning flie
Thorow my bloud, hath yet not ſuffered me
To parle with ſleep ſince th' unhappy act,
—I find them ſomething calm'd, and will attempt
To reconcile them in this gentle ſhade.

sp.stage: Lies down, having lain ſtill a while enter two Bandeets.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: We have loſt our company.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: No matter, we ſhall finde the way to Court,
I fear nothing but how we ſhall do to live honeſt.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.p: The place requires it not, at moſt 'twill be Enough to ſeem ſo.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: Though we never us'd it much, I doubt not
But Hypocriſie is an art eaſily learn'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Come let's haſten, I would willingly ſee thee
Between the King and the captive Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: Her captivity is like to be our redemption.

sp.speaker: 1. Bad.
sp.l: If it prove not ſo, we muſt dance off the
Stage in a halter—What do they call her name?
Heroina—daughter to the Cyprian king,
Betroth'd to ours a long time ſince, when he
Was abroad in his travels.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: 'Twill be a joyful meeting unto them.

sp.speaker: 2. Ban.
sp.l: Had we not had ill luck, a Bandeet had been his
Taſter.-.-They diſcover Oroandes.
How now, what have we here
—So ho—what art?—

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Tuſh, ſome drunk Forreſter, let him alone.

div.stage: Ex. Bandeets. Oroandes riſes.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Heroina!—A Princeſſe!
—And carying to the Court by Bandeets!
It is the unhappy Lady that was betroth'd
Unto my murthe • 'd Soveraign—lighted on
In their excurſions by theſe rennegadoes.
—Poor Lady—I have ſpoil'd her entertainment there;
—But I will follow them, and with my bloud
Crimſon the ſables that muſt cloud the day. Ex. Oroan.

div.stage: Enter Arratus, ſervants ſetting forth two thrones, the one richly adorned, the other covered in mourning, before the black throne a table, on which a Crown is laid on a mourniug cuſhion, before the other throne is plac't the picture of the King.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Come—come—ſee all things in order
The Princeſſe is at hand—fie—fie,
This is an unexpected trouble—
—A way you groſſe witted raſcall—doeſt not ſee
We ſtrive to paint our ſorrow in checquer'd work,
But this 'tis when women ſit at the helm of ſtate,
They ſquare all Court entertainments to the faſhion
Of the laſt Romance they heard. Shout and acclamations within.
Hark, they are enter'd the
Palace, I hear the Cannon—
Go off from the Forts—be gone—and make way.

div.stage: Loud muſick, the Lord high Marſhall, his white rod wreathed in black ribbon, next him, the King and Vanlore leading Heroina, her train born up by Theocrine.

At the other door (whilſt a ſoft and melancholly muſick playes within) Zannazarro, Glorianda, and Eurione all in mourning; Zannazarro kneels, and having kiſt Heroina's hand is raiſed by her, ſhe ſaluting the other Ladies.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: The beſt of welcomes this ſad place affords
Waits on your Graces entertainment.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And we • to do what ſervice lies within
The verge of our indevours—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I thank you both ſweet Ladies, and muſt firſt
Imploy your ſervice in declaring what▪
Theſe ſilent emblems of a ſorrow mean.
I have not ſeen grief in the like diſguiſe,
The lawrell and the ſunerall Cypreſs here
Have wreathed their ill met branches, and contends
Whoſe leaves ſhall Crown the Syracuſian queen.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Wil't pleaſe you aſcend your throne, and there
Lend your attention to the ſaddeſt ſtory
That ere did yet Siciliaes Annals blot?

div.stage: She aſcends the throne.
Zannazarro drawes the curtain from before it, and diſcovers the picture of the King.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Behold, great Princeſſe,
All but the memory of his living fame
Of Syracuſiaes Monarch. She ſounds and fals from the throne.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Oh help—help the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Madam—dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Oh—oh—God!—

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Bear her forth, and give her more air.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Hold—I am better here—if any thing
Revive my ſpirits, 'twill be this that puts
Me in the mind of my deceaſed Lord.
—Unhappy woman, firſt to know—then love,
Ingage thy faith, yet never to injoy!

div.stage: Enter Oroandes in his own habit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Why ſtand you thus amazed 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Pardon us Maclam—had the united duſt

Of ſome dead friend, whoſe memor 〈…〉
• ear forgot,
Viſited earth in his known ſhape again,
Our wonder could not have arrived unto
A higher pitch—
Let me imbrace thee friend▪

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l:
—My deareſt Or 〈…〉
—

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Stand off—yet farther off;
You know not what you touch,
You ſafer far may grapple with a flame,
Or in his midnights walk affront a fiend
Arm'd with full vials of deſtructive wrath.
The graves inhabitants, when folded in
Corruption, are not more defil'd then I.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: What tends this language to?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Deſtruction—Zannazarro.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: How haſt thou loſt thy temper Oroandes?
P • ithee look on me friend, or am I grown
A ſtranger to thy knowledge?—

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Leave me Eurione, thou art of kin
Unto thoſe hallowed Angels that did once
Attend my actions, and muſt now with them
A ſtranger to thy Oroandes grow.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Neglected thus!—Alas—where ſhall I weep?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You are to me a ſtranger Sir, yet in
Your look I ſomething read that may concern
Your abſent Prince, collect thoſe ſcattered ſpirits
Now roaving in confuſion, and relate it.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: I would, but that it hath a ſound ſo full
Of trembling horror, 'twill unnerve your joints,
—Yet I muſt do't, no other way can lead
My ſoul from out this wilderneſſe of fleſh
—He's murther'd.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: —By whom?—

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: This curſed hand; d'ee ſtart?
I thought 'twould ſtrike the bloud out of your cheeks,
And make you paler then the act made me.
'Twas I—'twas I, that when your blooming hopes
Chear'd with the ſun of Majeſty, were grown
Big with expected favours, did eclipſe
The glorious light in a black cloud of death.
I cut the heartſtrings of the Land, and fed
The groaning earth with bloud, whoſe purple had
Been by an ancient ſtock of anceſtors
Died into royalty.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Ingratefull ſlave, why are our ſwords ſo ſlow
—To execute the villain?

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Oh hold, believe him not—he raves,
Theſe are the births of a diſtemper'd brain.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Thou haſt but injured me Eurione
In ſtaining their juſt fury—farewel,
Reſt in E • izium whilſt I roar in hell. Eurione fals.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: —Oh brother, if this be true, thou haſt undone us all.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: True—do not think
'Tis any natural diſtemper that
Spreads this malignant vapour through my veins,
Which nought but th' poiſon of my guilt corrupts.
—No I have done it brother,
And you are all bound as you love your Prince
To ſee't reveng'd with torments, here's a note
Will when I'm dead direct you where to find him.
And now I've done my buſineſſe on the earth,
Ile give the firſt ſtroak to revenge, and here Sets the Sword to his breaſt.
Open a paſſage for your Swords to enter.

div.stage: As he is offering to ſtab himſelf the King ſtayes his hand.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: What bold hand is that?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: One that here may claim a priviledge, Throwes off his diſguize.
—Riſe thou mirror of true loyalty,
—Ne'r higher in our favour.

div.stage: They all kneel.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Our gratious Soveraign!—
—Welcome—oh welcome royall Sir!

sp.speaker: Kin.

lg.l: You are all my much loved Subjects, ſuch in whom
Never was king more bleſt—Madam
Your preſence crowns our bleſſings—now I ſtand
Exalted in the zenith of my fate.
Who would not paſſe a ſtormy night, to be
Thus courted by a lovely glorious day?
—You all are ſharers in my heart,
—But thou my Love— To Heroina.
The great commandreſſe of that royall fort.
—Off with theſe night p •• c't curtains, no ſuch vail
Shall cloud the perfect beauty of our joyes.

sp.stage: Puls off the black from the throne.

lg.l: Aſcend this throne, a place too humble for
Virtues ſo near allied to heaven as thine.
Now you expect the ſtory of my fate
In Syracuſ • s ſeeming Widowhood,
But the full ſea of pleaſure cannot yet
Contract its ſwelling waves, tumultuous joyes
Cannot be reconcil'd into diſcourſe,
Till Hymens topour to poſſeſſion lights
Our juſt deſires, that eldeſt childe of hope.
—I only have a promiſe to perform
Before you all unto this Gentleman,
And then will haſten to diſcharge the Arrears
〈…〉 and ingag'd in to your loyalty.
—Are the Priſoners ready?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: They wait at the door Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Go fetch them in, thou muſt my dear Ent. 2 Band • e • s leading Carlo.
Meet my firſt known imbraces, in the ſeat
Of long neglected Juſtice, ſet forth the Priſoners.
—My Lord—read the Indictment—

sp.speaker: Reads.
sp.p: Vincentio Carlo, you are here accuſed of a murther committed on a Syracuſian Gentleman, his name Vanl • re, the act done by two Souldiers whom you hired in the Camp at the ſiege of Ardenna: Guilty or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not guilty and pleaſe your good Grace, alas I never knew the man, I!—therefore I beſeech your Majeſty to be good to me, I am a poor ignorant man, and full of grief for the loſſe of my only daughter—

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: That will be proved an act of your own,—Read on.

sp.speaker: Reads.
sp.p: My Lord Arratus, you are here accuſed to be of confederacy with Signior Carlo in the murther of his daughter Theocrine.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Who I!—why I!—who dares?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Bandeets lay hold of him, where are the witneſſes?

div.stage: Enter two officers leading Creon and Lewcippus going lame and bound about the head.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Oh—oh—ſo weak, I am hardly able to go to the Bar.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I doubt we ſhall find it a harder march
To the Gallowes, but this I may thank thy villainy for.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Thou lieſt Raſcal, thou promptedſt me to all.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Read their accuſations.

sp.speaker: Reads.
sp.p: Creon and Lewcippus, you are hear accuſed for murthering Vanlore, at the ſiege of Ardenna, and being acceſſary to the death of Theocrine, daughter to Vincentio Carlo; Guilty or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Not guilty—my Lord, I confeſſe I was with this villain Lewcippus hir'd to do it, by this wretched Carlo, but had no hand in the murther, it was Lewcippus committed it.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I hope your Majeſty will not believe him,
For the Varlet is compoſed of falſehood,
In the death of Vanlore he was as far forth
As my ſelf, but for the loſſe of Theocrine
We neither of us had any hand in it,
It was a plot contrived by Carlo, and my Lord
Arratus, but for what ends we know not.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: I hope my good ſervice to your Majeſty
Hath merited better then to have my reputation
To be call'd in queſtion by a common Rogue.
I proteſt I will ſue the Raſcall for a ſlander,
—I will ſlave—by mine honour I will.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Swear not my Lord, by what you have abus'd;
Honour (that venerable title) was
Slain when to'th law you forfeited your life,
Bleeding to death at thoſe unworthy wounds
Which theſe low actions to high titles gave.
—Stand all forth, and attend your doom.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be merciful—oh good my Liege, be merciful.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: Swounds! I ſee I ſhall be cheated of my head.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Your actions merit none, yet ſince it is
The beſt companion of a Judge, we'l in
Her virgin zone the ſword of Juſtice wear.
—Diſcover your ſelves— Puls off the veil from Theocrine, at which Vanlore diſcovers himſelf.
Here are the witneſſes, brought to affirm our accuſation.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh let me go—they are Spirits,
Ghoſts—Hobgoblins—I will not ſtay,
This is ſome inchanted place.

sp.speaker: 1. Ban.
sp.l: Nay Sir, you are too faſt to ſtir.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: S-death! what jugling's this?

div.stage: Vanlore and Theocrine kneel to Carlo.

sp.speaker: Van
sp.l: Sir recollect your ſpirits—and beſtow
A bleſſing on us, both your children now.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay it is no point of my Religion to pray for the dead.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Sir we ſtill live, and live to want your prayers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I want my money more that theſe two Rogues have
Couſened me of, I hope your charity will
Make them reſtore it again, I am
An old man and like to come to want,
And every one hales what he can catch from me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Curſed Miſer, the Law will free thee from the fear of want;
For though thy damn'd intentions did not wade
So far as action into guilt—thy life
Is forfeited for the intended ſin. Vanlore and Theo. kneels.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If we were ever gracious in your eyes,
Let us beg pardon for him.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Their lives are yours, yet juſtice muſt not be
Robb'd of all intereſt in them, for your ſakes
We'll miti gate their puniſhments. All Carloes wealth,
That Devill which did tempt him to this ſin,
Being by the Law made forfeit unto us,
We with his daughter, the fair Theocrine,
Wholly beſtow on Vanlore.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh I am undone—I am undone,
I had better been hang'd out of the way
Then to have liv'd to have ſeen my goods
Thus gave away before my face.
—Oh that ever I was born!

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: For Arratus—becauſe he valued wealth
More then his honour, he ſhall ever loſe
Thoſe glorious titles, now grown burthenſome
Unto his age, which may betake it ſelf
To needfull reſt, whilſt all his places of
High truſt are by the worthier Vanlore managed.
On whom, as but a juſt reward unto
His merits, we beſtow them.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Your Majeſty will by your goodneſſe teach Me future gratitude—

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.l: And me perhaps repentance when too late.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: For theſe two villains, the baſe inſtruments
Unto your guilt, ſince we deſire to have
No bloud defile this dayes ſolemnity,
Let them by publick Edict be for ever
Excluded our Dominions. And now we've ſheath'd
The ſword of Juſtice, let me open wide
The armes of Friendſhip, unto you that have
Been maſqu'd in this Meander of our fate.
My debts are great to all, but muſt remain
In full arrear, untill my offerings paid
To ſacred Hymen, gives me liberty;
Whoſe Altars now we'l all prepare to warm
With the pureſt flame that ere Sicilia ſaw.
Come Heroina, let's conduct them to
The Temple, where united hands ſhall prove
Our cares are conquer'd by Victorious Love.
